The lack of credible evidence: The expert highlights that there is no substantial evidence to support the claim that 4,000 Israelis were warned in advance of the 9/11 attack. The absence of any concrete proof undermines the authenticity of the claim.
Inconsistencies with the facts: The expert points out that the claim contradicts the well-documented accounts of the thousands of deaths and the diverse range of individuals who perished in the World Trade Center attack. The claim's suggestion that only Israelis were warned and escaped harm goes against the known facts of the tragedy.
Propagandistic sources: The expert notes that the claim originated from sources known for their anti-Semitic, anti-Zionist, and anti-Israeli agendas. These biased sources raise doubts about the credibility and motives behind the claim, suggesting it may be driven by political propaganda rather than factual evidence.
Implausible motivations: The expert questions the rationality behind the claim, highlighting that it fails to provide any logical reasons as to why Israel would betray its ally, the United States, and allow thousands of innocent Americans to die. The lack of a convincing motive undermines the credibility of the claim.
